commentPreTextItems.html: 10.30am Zakir Hasan and Shadman Islam are in the middle. Jasprit Bumrah will start for India. Three slips and a gully.

Joe: "Surprised that Shakib's looming test farewell didn't get as much of a coverage as, I believe, it truly deserves. Sure, the guy had off field issues that dogged his almost entire career, but he DID bring value to BD cricket." --- I am pretty sure it will get the deserved attention. If you ask me, Shakib is Bangladesh's greatest cricketer ever.

Rohit Mehta: "I really feel for Kuldeep here. Poor guy has been outstanding over the last couple of years, and can't seem to get even a home test, this time at his home ground! Such is the calibre / conditions / riches we now have." --- Think the conditions also played a role today.

10.25 It was interesting to see how the two teams read the conditions differently. India opted to bowl first; Bangladesh wanted to bat first. India have gone in with three seamers and two spinners; Bangladesh have two seamers and three spinners. Let's see how it pans out.
Thanks, Sudarshanan and hello everyone.
10:21am Under nine minutes to go for ball one, Hemant Brar is all set and is set to call the first hour. Show him some love, and tell him what you think of both the XIs
10:10am As we wait for the game to start in about 20 minutes, do catch up on a piece of fun content. Our Line-up crew tried to pick India's best XI of the 21st century:

video.title: Pant or Dhoni? Pujara or Laxman? Who makes India's best Test XI of the 21st century?
video.seoTitle: Picking Indias best Test XI of the 21st century
video.summary: The Line-up crew settle on a combination after a fierce debate. Do you agree with them?

commentPreTextItems.html: Elsewhere, after India's double gold at the Chess Olympiad, the country is waking up to the brilliance of the sport again. In growing from big-city pockets to become a pan-India sport, can chess follow cricket?
Shishank Dahiya: "Having Ashwin and Jadeja at 7 and 8 provides India with great flexibility, allowing them to field five specialist bowlers without compromising their batting depth."

SMS: "Nice to see Akash getting a long run even though it comes at the expense of either Kuldeep who was the MOM in the last test he played or Axar who has been brilliant in last 2 years in all formats!! Tough competition everywhere!!"
10am Toss time! The coin lands in India's favour. India opt to bowl

Conditions played a role, Rohit says. Reckons the pitch is slightly soft. Wants to give his three seamers a chance to exploit the conditions. Talks about wanting to win games and finding ways to win Tests. India are unchanged

Shanto wanted to bat first, so both teams really happy. Expresses delight at his bowlers' show last game. Wants the batters to score big runs once they get a start. Important to handle the new ball, he says. Nahid and Taskin out, Khaled and Taijul in for Bangladesh
Sampath Bandarupalli says this is the first instance of teams winning the toss opting to bowl first in consecutive men's Test in India
You can check out the Playing XIs of both teams here

Jay Deshpande: "Shakib Al Hasan was one of the promising all rounder prospects of the 2000s, especially during the 2007 World Cup. It's hard to believe how long he has been around. Obviously his sportsmanship over the years has been questionable (last year's World Cup against SL was no exception). But I've respected the role he's played for Bangladesh and will rightly be called as one of the great all rounders of the modern era. Hope India likewise make as much use of Jadeja in the next couple of years."

9:55am Najmul Hossain Shanto is out with the Bangladesh blazer on. And Alagappan spots Akash Deep marking his run-up. In fact, it looks like India will be going in with three quicks. Weather could have had a role to play. And Rohit Sharma now emerges out of the dressing room with his blazer and baggy blue cap on. We'll find out all about the teams soon

poll.title: India's bowling mix for the Kanpur Test should be...

commentPreTextItems.html: 9:48am Al spots Siraj, Jadeja, Kuldeep and Bumrah going through the bowling exercises. So Akash could miss out, he reckons

Anand : "If the condition is overcast, could it be Yash Dayal coming in for maybe Siraj instead of Kuldeep?" Don't think a cap presentation happened in the team huddle, so no debut for Dayal as of now

9:44am Morne Morkel, India bowling coach: "What a wonderful week. I have always played against India and followed India after my playing days. Wonderful to be in this environment and see how the guys operate. It is a matter of looking to build experience [with the bowlers]. A lot of the series are going to be five-Test series. There is a lot of experience in this dressing room, but for the guys coming in, making sure they fit in and evolve. Start thinking about setting goals. I am a believer of mapping out journey for direction. If they can take it series by series and looking to improve. [How do you work with new bowlers like Dayal, Akash] Key is to make them feel at home. Once you allow them the space to learn and make mistakes, it is a great enviroment."
9:36am Toss at 10am, play to start at 10:30am

9:33am Al Muthu reports: "Inspection is going on right now. The umpires seem to be concerned with the extra cover boundary, a spot at mid off and deep midwicket for the right hander from the media box end. They're stomping down on the ground at each spot, looking to see if it gives way. Some of the players have started making their way out too. Support staff setting up equipment for their warm ups."

video.title: Manjrekar: KL Rahul is someone I will keep a close eye on
video.seoTitle: Manjrekar - KL Rahul is someone I will keep a close eye on
video.summary: Sanjay Manjrekar on the batter's underwhelming record in Test cricket

commentPreTextItems.html: Tanbir : "Can't Imagine this test could be Shakibs last.I may be one of them who dislike Shakibs off filed character but having said that I still believe he deserves a home test to end his career.What a cricketer he has been for BD.Hats off"
Malli: "I just hope this match continues here in Kanpur and doesn't turn to "CAN"POUR""
Nanda: "Should drop Ashwin to bring in Kuldeep.  Players in poor form should not be in the playing eleven." Do players out of form pick up five-wicket hauls and score hundreds? ;)

9:16am The deep extra cover region from the press box end seems to be the area of concern, notes Daya. There's a small matter of limited attendance allowed in the 'C' stand at Green Park. It has been deemed unsafe and so, only 1750 fans will be allowed there when it can actually seat 4800 people.

Azhar: "Bangladesh should consider bringing back Mahmudul Hasan Joy into the top order to reduce the number of left-handed batters, who have been struggling against inswing deliveries." He was the incumbent, wasn't he? Because Zakir and Shadman did well in a tricky situation in that first Test against Pakistan, they have managed to keep Mahmudul out. We'll see if Bangladesh switch it up this soon (hard to see, imo)
avesh: "Why is Daya using British era spelling of Cawnpore?" He says he was a student of modern history and just remembered his college days while posting that update

9:10am Ravindra Jadeja is one of the premier allrounders in the world, more so in Test cricket. He is on 299 Test wickets and will become the second-fastest to the double of 300 wickets and 3000 runs in the format. Al paid a glowing tribute to what makes Jadeja quite a force to reckon with - his speed and accuracy makes him deadly, he writes.
Just a reminder, you can follow all the updates from this India-Bangladesh Test LIVE in Hindi also
9:02am Pitch report: It is a black soil pitch, confirms Murali Kartik. It is dark but there's enough straw-coloured grass. Good track to bat but overcast skies could force a rethink he adds.

"Lots of activity on the ground right now," says Alagappan. "Morne Morkel was camped by the pitch, taking a good long look at it. He's just left. The square covers have been pulled back. The rest are slowly being pulled back as well. There was water pooled on those covers from the overnight rain. Two super soppers have also been roaming around."

video.title: Manjrekar: I will play Kuldeep Yadav in second Test
video.seoTitle: Manjrekar - I will play Kuldeep Yadav for second Test
video.summary: "Workload should not be an issue for Bumrah," he says

commentPreTextItems.html: SMS: "Might be the final test for Shakib considering the political scenario in Bangladesh. Whadda player and champion he has been for them!! One of the best allrounders ever to have played the game!!"
Shishank Dahiya: "It is bright and sunny for now in Greater Noida, can we move the match here?"
dhira: "why can't we cover whole ground? I don't think it is impossible. whats the point of keeping outfield open and then work hard to dry it?" Most of the ground was under covers

8:56am About four minutes to official toss time but Rohit is still in his training kit and having a light chat with match referee Jeff Crowe. And it is official - toss is delayed due to a wet outfield. An inspection is scheduled for 9:30am.
Neal: "Would love to see a newly confident Bangladesh give India a real contest over five days. I hope they win the toss and bat first.  "

video.title: Should Kuldeep Yadav be playing more Tests?
video.seoTitle: Should Kuldeep Yadav be playing more Tests?
video.summary: "He is a rare talent" - Sanjay Manjrekar makes a case for the spinner

commentPreTextItems.html: 8:47am Toss slightly delayed says Abhinav Mukund on the official broadcast. He has been playing Tests for seven years now but Kuldeep Yadav now has a chance to play his first at home. It is not a straightforward move, as if the surface is expected to get slower, India could be tempted to play Axar Patel for the quickness he provides. Which is why Al wonders if the Kanpur kid Kuldeep get a chance to weave his magic at home.

Mayur Kulkarni: "Please Daya, have your 'Daya' on this test at least, unlike when you were in Greater Noida when you failed to open your 'Daya Sagar' on that test match." Hahaha! Mayur, Daya says it is his home state and the match won't be a washout. The drainage system in Kanpur makes him hopeful

video.title: Akash Deep: 'Very fortunate to play for India under Rohit Sharma'
video.seoTitle: Akash Deep - 'Very fortunate to play for India under Rohit Sharma'
video.summary: India seamer on stepping up to international cricket, the strength of India's domestic cricket, on the Kanpur pitch, and more

commentPreTextItems.html: 8:42am "Both super-soppers pressed into service to dry the outfield. Ground staff are working on the pitch and the run-up area from the Press Box end," pings Daya Sagar from the ground. Let's talk a bit more about India now. They have named an unchanged side and the question is - three seamers + two spinners or two seamers + three spinners. Akash Deep has put in a strong case for him to be one of the two fast bowlers, if they do take that route. He spoke about how the domestic grind made it easier for him to play Test cricket. Al Muthu also spoke to a coach who kept an eye on Akash and gave an insight into his charge's deceptive pace.

video.title: Manjrekar: Bangladesh attack lacks quality and experience
video.seoTitle: Manjrekar - Bangladesh attack lacks quality and experience
video.summary: Sanjay Manjrekar on the visitors' chances in Kanpur

commentPreTextItems.html: 8:33am The Green Park last hosted a Test in 2021, when New Zealand hung on to a battling draw. There is a fair amount of mystery on the surface to be used today. Even so, the spotlight was not much on the pitch as it was on a certain Shakib Al Hasan. He announced that he is done with T20Is and expressed desire to finish his Test career in Mirpur next month. The Bangladesh Cricket Board, though, said it cannot guarantee Shakib's security for Bangladesh's home Tests against South Africa, and it could well be that this Kanpur Test could be his last.
Arindam : "Hope this is the first comment of the day… Hope Kanpur presents another exciting Test match. "

video.title: Manjrekar: I will play Kuldeep Yadav in second Test
video.seoTitle: Manjrekar - I will play Kuldeep Yadav for second Test
video.summary: "Workload should not be an issue for Bumrah," he says

commentPreTextItems.html: 8:25 am Good morning folks, and welcome to ESPNcricinfo's coverage of the second Test between India and Bangladesh in Kanpur. Both the teams may have moved on from Chennai after a whopping win, but they seem to have taken the overcast weather along with them. The news from the venue is that there was rain overnight and it's overcast this morning. Fingers crossed we start on time. There is rain forecast for at least the first three days of the Test match and that could add to the intrigue surrounding the team combination, notes Hemant Brar in the preview

commentTextItems.html: starts with a loosener. Around good length but way outside off and moving further away from the batter. Interestingly, it bounced once again before reaching Pant
this is more like Bumrah we know. An absolute pearl of a delivery. Around good length, around off stump, forcing the batter to play and then beating him with the away movement
this one starts way down the leg side and moves in late. Zakir fails to connect the flick
great shape from Bumrah, Think this one pitched just outside leg and moved away from the batter to beat the outside edge
After four awayswingers, Bumrah tries to bring this one in but misses his length. It's full and down the leg side and Pant can do nothing about it
slightly fuller than good length and coming into Zakir. He defends it on the leg side

dismissalText.commentary: Zakir Hasan c Jaiswal b Akash Deep 0 (24b 0x4 0x6 39m) SR: 0

commentTextItems.html: an excellent catch by Jaiswal and Deep has struck in his first over. The umpires, though, want to check the fairness of the catch. It was a length ball outside off. Zakir came forward to defend. Hard hands and gets a thick outside edge that goes low to the right of Jaiswal at slip. He goes with both hands but replays are too blurry to judge if the ball bounced before he caught it. Finally, there is one angle from which the TV umpire concludes that it went straight into the hands. And he also says there is no angle which shows the ball bounced. So Zakir departs for a 24-ball duck

dismissalText.commentary: Shadman Islam lbw b Akash Deep 24 (36b 4x4 0x6 54m) SR: 66.66

commentTextItems.html: a huge, huge appeal for lbw, especially from the bowler. Rohit has gone for the review after a bit of discussion. Was a length ball that came in with the angle. Shadman was on his toes as he looked to flick it. Got beaten and the ball-tracking shows it hit him slightly down the middle stump and would have gone on to hit a good chunk of leg stump. Bangladesh lose their second wicket. From the first replay it seemed umpire's call at best but when the projection came up, even Rohit couldn't believe it

commentPreTextItems.html: One left-hand batters goes, another walks in. Here's Shanto

length ball in the channel. Left alone
full around off. Shanto comes forward and drives it through the vacant mid-off region

commentPostTextItems.html: And it's drinks. Sudarshanan is back for another stint

commentPreTextItems.html: Siraj back on for another spell

Thanks Hemant. I thought Bangladesh openers had done quite well for most part of the hour. They had managed to see off the opening spells of Bumrah and Siraj. But enter Deep. His probing lines and lengths had the openers hoping, and eventually walking back to the hut. Some spell this, but Shanto seems to be carrying on from Chennai. Let's see how he counters the next hour

commentTextItems.html: Full and slanting across off, just about carried to the keeper
Fuller on off, Mominul taps it in front of cover and sprints to get off the mark on his 15th ball
Soft hands gets Shanto his third four in six balls. Lunges forward to defend the length ball with a wobble seam that is angled across. Gets an outside edge that goes between gully and the cordon

Celebrappeal from Siraj but the umpire does not think so. Pant seems to have convinced Rohit for the DRS. This one lands on a length and shapes back in a touch. Shanto hops to flick it away but is beaten on the inside edge and is hit on the flap of the pad. Did it land in line? Nope, pitched outside leg. India lose a review

commentImages.caption: Mohammed Siraj was confident about his lbw appeal but it cost India a review
commentImages.longCaption: Mohammed Siraj was confident about his lbw appeal but it cost India a review, India vs Bangladesh, 2nd Test, 1st day, Kanpur, September 27, 2024

commentPreTextItems.html: Abhi: "Both the DRS calls that India have taken in this inning look "weird" on TV. The successful one looked like it was missing leg and the current one to Shanto appeared to have pitched inline and heading for the stump. I don't know if this is the effect of ageing eyesight or if the DRS on TV looks off!" The Deep lbw call was mainly because of the lowish bounce Green Park is known for. The Siraj appeal was a pure error in judgement. So nothing off with DRS

Too many runs are leaked in that direction through edges which is really demotivating and frustrating for bowlers." The bowlers want the edges to go to slip and not over or away from them. So starting with a fielder at deep third will make it a slightly defensive move

Huge appeal, an afterthought from Bumrah. And India opt for the review. Bumrah bowls it on a length around off and nips it back in. Mominul goes back to defend but clearly does not counter for the inward movement and is hit on the back flap. While the wicketkeeper and slips went up in appeal, Bumrah joined them later. Hawk-Eye shows it to clipping the stumps
Nips back in from a length on middle and leg, hit high on the front leg

commentPostTextItems.html: 12:33pm Covers come on just as players make their way off the field. The rain also seems to have intensified. The ground staff have swiftly covered the pitch with more areas of the outfield soon getting shielded. Hopefully it does not hamper resumption. But for now, what a session this was. Bangladesh can well stake claim for it. They lost just the two wickets despite India bowling superbly well. Bumrah and Siraj made the new ball hoop around, Akash Deep's discipline saw him strike twice in his first 13 balls. But Shanto has carried on from his fine knock in the Chennai Test. And Mominul has done well to keep him company despite not looking all at ease. Join us back in about half an hour. Hemant will be here, hopefully, with good news.

commentPostTextItems.html: 2:52pm Unfortunately, official news trickling in that it is stumps on day one in Kanpur. It hasn't stopped raining and I am not sure the light would have improved later on. So all we have from the opening day of the second Test are 35 overs. In that, Shanto and Mominul showed their mettle. Akash Deep showed his guile with the new ball while Ashwin showed his nous in setting Shanto up for a dismissal. How we wish we had more of this. Not to be, as rain has the final say for today. And that means play should start half an hour early on the second day. Do join us then for all the live updates. Till then, take care and stay safe aficionados!

Adam: "Is there more rain in the forecast in the coming days? Might not be destined for a result in this one." There is a bit of rain in forecast tomorrow too. Let's hope we get a good chunk of play, though
2:38pm The rain has not relented. If anything, the visuals have only got gloomier. Think we are in for a longish wait
2:23pm There is a drizzle around and it has gotten slightly heavier, Daya says. Pictures also look quite gloomy. Proper rain at the moment, it's "POURING MAD" Al writes to me in all caps

Jalda Sandeep: "There is always talk of Cricket Ground Venues to be rotated so that all get equal opportunity to host international cricket but what i feel is unless the ground has proper equipment, ground staff, lights and facilities they should not be awarded the match especially Tests.. as a gully cricketer myself in local matches faced issues related to ground and mismanagement of wicket.. it leaves sour taste for the players.. This being international cricket, that has to be a norm to be followed.." Green Park has most of the things you have mentioned, Sandeep. Just that it is raining and can't really control that. The whole ground is under covers, like the grounds in Sri Lanka are done.
2:13pm There was rain in forecast around 2pm, and it has not yet arrived. But covers are being brought on now.

Chandu: "Introduce "Umpire's call" for pitching just outside leg stump (say 1 cm), where review is not burnt :)" There is no projection element in the ball pitching, so not sure an ump's call is needed in there
Raju M Iyer : "@ Natesh : Hope the concept of Impact Player is extended from T20 to Tests; then we can have Shami come in for Akash Deep in 2nd innings!"
And with that, Sudarshanan is back in the hot seat.

2.08pm It has become pretty dark out there, and the players are walking off. So we have had nine overs after lunch, in which Bangladesh scored 33 runs and lost the wicket of Shanto - Ashwin trapped him lbw.

commentPreTextItems.html: 9.29am Mominul turned 33 yesterday and is closing in on a half-century. He has the experienced Mushfiqur for company. Akash Deep has the ball, with three slips and a gully. Let's get some action here!

9.27am We're minutes away from the first ball of the day, after nearly one-and-a-half days! People have started trickling into the ground although it's a Monday morning so we can't expect it to be like yesterday.

BK: "Is this still considered Shakib's last test match, given the comments by BCB recently?" Not if South Africa tour Bangladesh, which is still a possibility. Shakib wants to play his last Test at home.

Bumrah: Weather is not in your control, it is the way it is. Good to get some time to relax. You've to quickly adjust to the changing conditions here after Chennai, quickly adapt and communicate with others, like about changing lines and lengths. My favourite format is the Tests, I've always said that. I'm trying to give my absolute best in this format. you have to be smart (to stay fit for Australia) and it's good to get some overs under the belt here although the number of overs to be bowled will be a lot more in Australia.

Som: "India will loos PCT points if this test draws out?" Yeah, they won't get as many points with a draw compared to a win. But Indian fans shouldn't worry much because India are already on top and have three more home Tests coming up, against New Zealand who have just been swept 2-0 in Sri Lanka

Shubham: "Quirks of our game. Rather than starting early and playing early when it is bright sunshine, the game will be extended in the last session when light could be iffy." Well, the good thing is there's hardly any rain in the forecast today and tomorrow, according to the broadcaster

Avinash : "How's the pitch will behave now.... After under cover for almost 2 and half days ..... Whom will get benefitted " There could be some early movement as we see usually in the morning in India, but otherwise it's expected to be good for batting.
9.10am Time for the pitch report: Athar Ali Khan reckons the pitch has dried out nicely so conditions should be good for batting apart from some early movement.
DanCricFan : "Q: do revised session times imply stumps are guaranteed at 5p because the extra ½hr has already been factored in?" That extension could take it to 5.30pm, light permitting
Roop: "Only India's aim is wrap up Bangla and Play one session and declare, bowl out Bangla, and lastly, chase the target." Easy peasy, eh?

9.05am It's bright and sunny, I repeat, really bright and sunny! There's a lot of activity on the ground, and this time from the players unlike yesterday. Mushfiqur is out there with his batting gear, Kohli and Rohit are wearing sunglasses (it's so bright), and everyone's moving around nicely, putting fears of a wet outfield to bed. We're set to start at 9.30am! Here are the revised session timings:
First: 9.30am - 11.45am
Second: 12.25pm - 2.40pm
Third: 3pm - 5pm

8:55am We are into the fourth day of the Test. In the first three days, we got only 35 overs in. And all of those on the first day. While there was constant drizzle on Saturday, there was no rain at all on Sunday and yet we could not witness any cricket action. Thanks to the farce, Alagappan writes about how Green Park made cricket disappear

jasbir singh: "What will be the start time? Is it not possible to start play at 0900 hrs and continue it unil 1730 to make up some lost time." The start time has stayed 9:30am IST despite the loss of time

8:40am A very good morning, indeed! Bright news to start the day as Alagappan reports that there is sunshine in Kanpur. Daya Sagar adds that the pitch and the ground are all uncovered. Umpires and the ground staff are near the fine leg region from the media box end to inspect the area. Let's see how this goes. Bangladesh have already started warming up, while India are setting up their stuff to begin, adds Daya
<hr>

2.35pm That's all for today, I'm afraid. There's lots happening in cricket otherwise since you all must be hungry to consume something this Sunday. Sri Lanka have swept NZ 2-0 with an innings win in Galle, England and Australia are getting ready for an ODI series decider in Bristol, and there was loads of IPL news coming in about the retention rules, match fees, and what not. We will have a live video analysis happening at 3pm IST (not long from now) along with our in-house experts and ace T20 coach Tom Moody about the latest rules and what kind of retention plans each franchise would chalk out. Stay tuned on our homepage for that. We also saw India's T20I squad announced last night, which handed a maiden call-up to the latest speed sensation Mayank Yadav. What else came out of the squad? Yash Jha guzzled some coffee and wrapped all of it here:

video.title: Takeaways: A first look at Mayank Yadav
video.seoTitle: Takeaways: A first look at Mayank Yadav
video.summary: Yash Jha with the takeaways from India's squad announcement for the Bangladesh T20Is

commentPreTextItems.html: And with that, it's goodbye and good luck from me, Vishal Dikshit, and Hemant. Ciao!

"shld there be a reserve day for all test matches which can be used only if a certain number of overs have been lost and on the consent of both thr captains" I doubt if the current cricket calendar allows for that, Rohan satish

2.20pm There will be plenty of questions after this kind of a day. 1) Does this ground's drainage facilities need an upgrade? 2) Should the Indian grounds also start covering the field completely when it rains heavily, like they do in Sri Lanka? 3) What else could the ground staff have done to make some play possible since there was no rain today? 4) Should Test matches be held only at grounds with really good drainage and other such facilities for play to start quickly after rain? How will the other grounds get any Test cricket then?

There's also a stat after no play on the day! Courtesy Sampath: 35 overs bowled in Kanpur are the second-fewest across the first three days of a Test match since 2014. Only 22 overs of play was possible across the first three days of the Port of Spain Test between West Indies and India in 2016. No play was possible in that match on the last two days.
The only good news for Bangladesh is that it's Mominul Haque's birthday today. He turns 33 so they can have a longer party in the hotel or wherever they want to celebrate!
ashish: "I can understand poor drainage. But the entire ground was covered and still we didnt get a single ball bowled when no rain happened today. These things should be investigated."

Mukundan: "Shame that Kanpur ground was not able to have the ground match ready despite no rain and bright sunshine the whole day today. Such grounds should be taken up by BCCI to modernise and better them. Crucial WTC points India could be potentially losing here!"
And to run salt and whatever on our wounds, the sun is out in Kanpur soon after play has been called off.

Yugeesha: "The way Sri Lanka covers the enter ground without ensuring no spills is something other countries need to look into and implement. it is quite sad as a cricket fan to see games or days of cricket called off due to wet outfields."

2.08pm Right, the official word is "play has been called off due to wet outfield". There was overnight rain in Kanpur, but like Hemant said no rain at all since morning. There have been at least three inspections today, all without the covers on the field, and with plenty of wet patches in the outfield. Alagappan told us that the groundstaff tried to dry parts of the outfield for the first hour. But after that the activity was nonexistent. This is, obviously, far from ideal conditions. The priority is always players' safety when we want to resume play after some rain and the way the umpires were always checking the dampness and sponginess on the ground, it never looked like we were going to have much play today. So three days done and we've seen only 35 overs so far.
Sriram Iyer: "Sad to see a day washed out due to wet outfield even though there has been no rains today. we need to look at astro trufs now "
Over to Vishal for the last rituals for the day.
2.02pm And play has been called off officially, despite no rain since morning.
2pm More from Alagappan: "They're briefing the team officials now, pointing at those spots at mid off. And as they separated they all shook hands. And we all know shaking hands is a bad sign."
1.55pm The umpires are out there now for the inspection.
1.50pm Alagappan Muthu tells me that there's "ab-so-lute-ly nothing" happening on the field. "The only people out there now are the host broadcasters prepping for a show."
Ram: "Every Test .. tests a player's skill...This one, is testing our patience :)"
Rakin: "Hemant Bro! Are we getting some game today or not?" --- We will get to know that soon. The umpires will come out for an inspection in 20 minutes from now.

Vicky: "Considering the massive amount of time lost and in the interest of the game, let Bangladesh bat as long as they can when the play resumes. India declare their first innings and Bangladesh their second innings without batting a ball thereby eventually setting a target for India which they can look to chase down on the 5th day." --- Don't think Bangladesh are going to risk a Test like that. By the way, the last time it happened, things didn't go well.

Snehith: "@Preetesh Dhoni last played in July 2019. The rules didn't mention retirement and only that they should have played/contracted nationally 5 years ago. Sandeep Sharma is not retired but he can be a beneficiary of this rule as well." --- The earlier rule did say retirement, but yes, it now includes the likes of Sandeep Sharma and Siddarth Kaul.
1.15pm Another 45 minutes before the inspection...

Preetesh Achrek: "@Hemant The rule earlier was that a player should be retired for five years to be called as an uncapped player. If the same was applied now, Dhoni could not have been classed as an uncapped player as he retired on 15th Aug 2020 making him eligible for the uncapped slot post IPL 2025. So it clearly shows that not only the old rule has been brought back but has also been tweaked to accommodate Dhoni."

Swapnil: "Although people may point out the Dhoni rule existed before 2021, but there was a reason it wasn't used. If a capped Indian player is good enough to be retained by franchise, it's highly probable he would be featuring for national team as well. If Dhoni is retained, this would be first use of this rule ." --- Or it's to Dhoni's credit that he remains such a valuable asset even five years after his <del>retirement</del> last game.

Harpreet Singh : "People are talking about all these big franchises - RCB, LSG etc trying to get Rohit Sharma and other big players. But don't be surprised if it is Punjab who walks away with big names. Remember they have already made a big move by getting Ponting." --- And Ponting and Rohit have worked together at MI previously.

Baldi: "@Ujjwal: There was no real rule change for Ohtani in MLB. The 'designated hitter' rule, was there in the American League, where he started off (LA Angels), long before Ohtani reached the states."

Ujjwal: "In baseball, the MLB board had to resort to a rule change accommodating the generational talent (Ohtani), and it was unofficially named the 'Ohtani rule'. The media need to use the same term and name the new rule 'Dhoni rule' so everybody knows who is being favoured/accommodated." --- To be fair, this rule was there from the start and was scrapped only in 2021. You can read more here.
Kallu: "Wonder whether there is any accountability? Paying public should be informed of the action taken against the incompetence."
Siva Bala: "Test venues should be selected based on some strict criteria..... very good drainage system should be on top of the list "

Balashankar: "The rule about players getting banned if they withdraw after being picked in the auction looks perfect at the outset. But wouldn't it be more fair if it is done in cases where the franchise registers a complaint? There could be a case like that of Jofra Archer where the franchise picks the player knowing he won't be available for the season. Or there could be a genuine case of a personal issue coming up. And what about an injury? Blanket ban seems unfair, lot of clarity needed." --- Those with a genuine case are exempt. The IPL will check with the player's home board to confirm genuine/injury cases.

Atul Gujar: "Why are we constantly discussing about the IPL. this is the international test and loss of opportunity of another win and possible loss of important point. if this goes to draw, we may repent this decision of having the test in Kanpur. Sad, this is not the talk of the town and again the issue is swept under the carpet." --- Think that's what we were discussing until now.
Mustafa Moudi: "Dont think Rohit Sharma would like to continue with MI. Same for KL Rahul with LSG. So LSG must aim for Rohit while RCB must go for KL Rahul !!"
12.35pm Thanks, Vishal. The wait simply continues... And yes, I have been going through all the IPL rules and discussing set theory with Shiva Jayaraman.
Now time to welcome Hemant back, who has read through all the latest IPL happenings in the last couple of hours. Ask him all your doubts.

12.09pm Here you go: The next inspection is at 2pm, unfortunately. There are a lot of fans out there in the stands on Sunday but they'll have to keep waiting for another couple of hours at least. The curator is apparently hoping they see some sunlight soon so that the wet patches dry up quickly.

ashish: "@Vishal - yes we read sbout the deck being cleared for dhoni. I dont sbout others but looks like thala wants to retire as a villain. He has achieved everything in cricket. He doesnt need to keep playing. I know he has enough money. Money cant be the reason. Is it fame that he strives for more?" Or could just be his love for the game and fans. Imagine, cricket is the only thing he has known about his professional life since he was a teenager. It's hard to let that go completely.
Back to the IPL. Did you know the decks have been cleared for MS Dhoni to be retained as an "uncapped player". Details are all in here.
Veer: "BCCI should make a list of 5 Grounds, and Test Matches only in them.."

Pradeep Narayan: "It's really pathetic, seems Green Park does not have proper drainage system. The other day when 4th ODI Eng V Aus was played at Lords had delayed start due to heavy overnight rains, however we all know how good drainage system at Lords. Hence they could had a short successful 39 over game either side."
Avik Bhatter : "RCB - is like South Africa in ICC tournaments "

12pm The inspection is underway, the two umpires are out there with the chief curator. It's still pretty overcast there and the officials are all pressing certain parts of their ground with their shoes to check how damp or spongy it is still. Saba Karim on the host broadcaster says they sprinkled some sawdust before the inspection. Alagappan says the spot at mid-off to a right-hander facing up from the media box end got a lot of attention during the inspection. The officials are chatting among themselves and have just communicated something to the representatives of both teams - Raghu (the throwdown specialist for India) and Bangladesh's team manager. Let's see what comes out of it...

Meanwhile, Arun is on the IPL beat: "I dont think MI will be able to retain both Surya an Bumrah, along with Hardik..So RCB should target whomever comes out in auction.. Captaincy problem also solved"
11.53am Activity has been spotted! The fourth umpire is out there now with possibly the head groundsman, Alagappan says
Sudhakar : "Fourth umpire? What's that?" The name is Virender Sharma
James: "It's kinda pathetic that in 2024 we have to wait for field to dry so play can continue. There's gotta be a better way. "
AT: "Why were Bangladesh not penalised for slow over rate last game?" I guess because they were not so slow?

meet: "what's the situation on ground? how active is the ground staff? how's the weather, is the sun shining again?" Under 20mins to go for the inspection and Alagappan tells me it's the same as it's been since morning. No rain, no covers, no work being done.

11.30am It's officially lunch and we're half hour away from the next inspection so utilise this time carefully. Make a trip to the kitchen or watch an episode of your favourite series or just stay here like Rakin, who is getting restless.
Rakin: "Oh, 12 o'clock! Hurry up, I'm begging you! You're moving slower than my Wi-Fi on a rainy day!"
Or let us know your answer to this beautiful question...

video.title: Runorder - Should Virat Kohli captain RCB once again in the IPL?
video.seoTitle: Should Virat Kohli captain RCB once again in the IPL?
video.summary: The Runorder crew on the big question heading into the upcoming IPL auction

commentPreTextItems.html: Abdul Qadir : "You guys want to continue this match in galle? Should be free after tea today !!" It won't go on till tea, sir
"Yes I agree please move this match to galle, as a Bangladeshi fan I'd be ecstatic" Living up to your name, Arman
11.05am IPL fans, the retention rules were out last night. Have you had a look yet? Here you go (RTM is back)
Naseef: "Scored a perfect 10 in the quiz, make it more difficult!"

"I think there is still enough incentive for young players to play red ball cricket. Representing Indian at test level and getting a central contract will open more avenues and will be long term beneficial compared to IPL contracts." Fingers crossed, Shubham Srivast. There was an incentive for Test players too.
Abby: "6/10...it feels that kinda day as well..."

RajatMaheshwari: "Hey Vishal. Left the quiz midway as it was too tough to remember about all the datas and matches. Apart from the game, what do you think about new IPL retention rules and match fees introduction? Do you think it will make IPL a bit more competitive as more players will go to auction." Not sure if making it more competitive was the intention, if there's scope for that at all. But it's great news for the domestic players, say who get sold around their base price. But the flip side is, more and more Indian domestic players might not want to play the red-ball format now. I'm not sure if the match fee introduction was necessary.

Aiman: "Ofc the ipl had to keep the impact player rule. Didn't the board say something about scrapping the idea earlier this year?" They had said they were talking to the franchises whether to keep it or not.
"Didn't do better than my  overall academics. 5/10. Consistency is the key." Always, Abhijeet. And stick to the basics.
Rabbul: "The way srilanka is playing test, they are well in chance of playing WTC final this year. Can we expect all asian final." Four wickets away from an innings win

"Hey, Feeling sad cause it might be Shakib's last test and the weather is not permitting me to see him bat. Can I atleast have my first ever comment published here after trying for 1000th time in last 2 decades?" That's an average of 50 comments a year, so roughly once a week. You might have to up your game, Rakin
Erik : "Easi-ish quiz. 8/10."
hassan: "9/10 I thought it said most 5 wicket hauls for Bangladesh and didn't see the wins part..."
Azhar: "I believe Bangladesh has a strong chance of securing their first victory against South Africa next month, and possibly even winning their first series against them.
pratik: "How frustrating it is for a cricket fan when you wait for complete week for action on weekends and it gets washed out."

10.45am Thanks Hemant. And greetings one and all. We have some time to kill - the next inspection is at 12pm - and let's start with this Quiz: Apart from India, which is the only other Test nation that Bangladesh are yet to beat? Don't forget yo share how many you got right.
Bot10: "I got 9/10 on guesswork" Bots also do guesswork? Good to know
Mahi: "10/10.. Epic Win... Haha" Just one question - are you capped or uncapped?
"South Africa is the answer" Take the whole quiz, Tanjim! No short cuts
"Were BD penalised for slow over rate in the last match?" Nope, Amey

Siddhesh: "Is the entire ground not kept covered? Are these wet patches due to the water seeping through the cover. Really wish we had better facilities." There's been no rain since early morning so all the covers have been off for a while. Hard to say if the water leaked through or not, but the outfield has very wet patches.
Rafiq Fahim: "This match is going to be drawn i think. btw   I wish Shakib could get a hundred here. "
Over to Vishal Dikshit for the next hour or so.
"There's work starting to be done on those spots," says Alagappan. "Ground staff are at the one at mid-off trying to get it dry and safe."
Chandran: "Will Bangladesh also be allowed same Percentage that India gets FOR THIS MATCH,  in case of No play at all?" --- Yeah, both teams will get four points each in case of a draw.

10.10am More about the inspection from Alagappan: "The umpires have been checking a few different spots. Mid-off, cover, gully, first and second slip all for a right-hander facing up to the media box end. The next inspection is at 12pm." Which basically means we have lost the first session.
In one area near the boundary line, a lot of sand has been used to make the ground somewhat sturdy.

A few minutes ago Murali Kartik and Athar Ali Khan also did a ground and pitch report. They mentioned there are a few soggy patches near the bowler's run-up and mid-off and mid-on area. The pitch, obviously, has lots of moisture, which the Indian fast bowlers will look to take advantage of.
10am The umpires are out there for an inspection.

Niroop : "India already have lost a match to rain in WI in this WTC cycle. If this one goes the same way and if they lose more matches to rain against NZ, it will be a very unfortunate way to be kicked out of the final"

Vinay: "What will be the impact for Ind for WTC final if this game is a washout?" --- Given India were the favourites to win, a draw will cost them eight points. So it will impact their WTC final chances but it's difficult to say how much straightaway because there are way too many permutations and combinations possible right now. You can read more here.
Aashish Calla: "The first Test ended in 10 sessions, so there's still hope for a result in this one - Specially since now there will be a lot of help for the seamers here and India have 3 good ones."
Nitin : "BD already 107 is a big boost, they should get to 300 and declare today." --- I will be very, very surprised if Bangladesh declare their first innings for anything under 450.
9.40pm Alagappan pings: "No covers anywhere on the outfield. They're painting the lines on the popping crease on either side. Didn't seem like this would be possible this early last evening!"
Rabbul: "Goal for Indian team today to wrap up the BD innings under 200 and bat like ODI and put 400 on board. I think we can get the result by the end of tomorrow." --- Easier said than done!
jasbir singh: "Does this rain help batters or bowlers?" --- I think bowlers. Should be lots of moisture in the surface.
9.25am More good news. The main cover has also been removed and the whole ground is uncovered now.
Rafsan: "Just saw the pitch getting uncovered. I guess it's been covered since the first day. How good would that be for Indian Pacers!"
Ishaan: "Alagappan, by 'anytime soon', how far away do you reckon a start is" --- If the inspection is at 10am, and everything is fine, I think we can start by 10.30am.

9.15am Here's more from Alagappan Muthu: "We won't be getting a start soon. But once again, the team buses are expected. A big crowd has gathered for them again. False alarm. The crowd is dispersing."

Abinash Das: "The rainy scenes remind me of the 2015 Bengaluru Test. We watched Day 1 excitedly, eagerly awaiting India's batting on Day 2, only for rain to cancel it entirely. Instead, we roamed the stadium, soaking in the atmosphere and sharing our frustration with fellow fans and taking photos of players."

Ramakrishna : "India needs more stadium with bangalore stadium like technology for rainy  season Tests. Till then bangalore must be one of Mandatory  venue for every test series in Rainy season. Other season tests can be allocated to old technology stadium"

9am Welcome back. We have two updates, one good and one bad. The good news is it's overcast but not raining. The weather should improve further by noon. The covers have been removed from the outfield. Three super soppers are doing their job. The bad news is there was overnight rain and the main square is still under covers. The ground staff is using sponge to remove the water from the main cover. That means the start has been delayed. There will be an inspection at 10am.
<hr>

2:04pm Day 2 has been called off! This was always on the cards, once drizzle chose to play hide and seek throughout the morning. The overnight rains did not help either. No sun to dry any of the wetness underneath the sheets, too. Tomorrow the weather forecast is quite better - don't rejoice, there is a bit of rain around. Should not be as bad as today though. Fingers crossed. That's all we have from the Kanpur Test today, do join us tomorrow nice and early. Goodbye and take care.

Mahi: "My favorite memory is when Tamim scored 151. Bangladesh was in a good position at 290-3, then collapsed... I thought Bangladesh could have put up a tough fight if they had set a target around 200."

1:58pm The rain has reduced to a drizzle, and they played through this before lunch yesterday, says Alagappan. And he has spotted the umpires walking out to speak to the ground staff. It was a very short chat and they have gone back to the change room

Neamat Ullah: "In 2010, just before the first Test of the series, Virender Sehwag commented that Bangladesh's bowling attack was ordinary and that they couldn't claim 20 wickets from their opponents. However, in that Test match in Chittagong, Bangladesh responded by taking 18 wickets. Although they ultimately lost the match, it was the first time we saw a spark of fight from them until the very end in a Bangladesh-India Test. That remains my favorite memory of this rivalry in the longer format."

1:45pm Rain is back, Alagappan pings. "Forecast was for heavier showers but they haven't come. With the ground taking a lashing from yesterday and there being no sunshine today, it's tough to clear the water off the covers, let alone the outfield underneath."

Niraj Dhoot : "Favourite ind bangladesh test series memory has to be the sachin kumble comical run out mixup. The entire dressing room was laughing." It was ruled as a couple of runs and both batters actually survived that run-out
Huzefa: "The EPIC last wicket partnership of Sachin & Zak."
S

commentTextItems.html: 133.8kmh, on good length outside off and Mushfiqur defends it on he back foot
beaten with an outswinger! Pitched up this time with good seam position for the away swing, the batter drives on the off side and is beaten by the shape
much straighter now on middle and leg, he clips it to square leg
137.6kmh, drops it shorter now outside off, not far from off stump and Mushfiqur pokes and misses this time. Good bounce for Akash Deep
135.9kmh, jagging in this time from similar length and it's gone past the ribs to the keeper down leg
a solid, confident defence to end the over. Mushfiqur leans into that length ball outside off and sends Mominul back for the single

commentTextItems.html: 133kmh, not too quick but he pitches it on target around off for the angle and beats Mominul straightaway
much shorter and well outside leg. There's good bounce and Mominul tucks it to square leg
131.1kmh, goes back to the outside off line, but this time a bit too wide and he lets it go for the angle
137.3kmh, Bumrah picks up some pace but this one doesn't bounce as much as Mominul shoulders arms for the length ball angling away
137.7kmh, and beaten! A teasing length on off stump, Mominul wants to drive off the front foot but the ball seams away just a bit to beat the outside edge
ends the over with another leave outside off for the ball angling away. No damage done

Length, aimed at the top of off, 138.7kph, defended off the back foot towards point

" For starters I would be happy to get some cricket after two washed out days. And I guess i would be happy to draw a Test in India...

commentTextItems.html: Nearly chopped on. Angling in on a length, it moves back in a touch as well. Mushfiqur prods forward and hangs his bat out to defend but is lucky it does not brush leg

Knocked him over! An error in judgement from Mushfiqur costs him. I think he looked at the bounce of the previous ball and let this one go. Bumrah bowled it on a similar length - slightly fuller if anything, and angled it in from outside off. Mushfiqur thinks it is safe enough to pass over off but nope. Clips top of off!

commentTextItems.html: Cracked away nicely. Length ball on the fifth stump channel. Litton leans into it and drives it nicely through cover-point. NIce balance
Length ball on fourth stump, defended in front of cover
This is even better. Fuller and outside off, Litton comes half-forward and drives it off the meat of the blade through covers
Length ball angling in from outside off, he trusts the bounce and leaves it be

commentPreTextItems.html: Wow. The ball before Mushfiqur's dismissal pitched and deviated in 2cms, as per broadcast. The dismissal ball pitched exactly on the same spot and nipped in 6cm.! Bumrah magic

commentTextItems.html: Bowls on the pads and pays the price. Litton leans forward and clips it through square leg to pick up a third boundary in the over
Another length ball around off, keeps very low, Litton does well to keep it out

Fuller around off, pushed to cover

commentPreTextItems.html: Mohammed Siraj for the first time today. Just one wide slip and a gully for him over the wicket

commentTextItems.html: Has Mominul fended it to short square leg? The umpire thinks so but Mominul has gone up. Siraj starts his spell with a back of a length ball on leg, he goes back to clip it away. No inside edge, as per Snicko. It lobs off his thigh pad and Jaiswal takes a few steps forward to his right and takes it
Controlled pull to bring up a fantastic half-century. Short and on the body, he swivels and pulls it past backward square leg
Full and outside off, comes half-forward and defends to cover
Length ball slanting away, defended towards gully
Length ball going away, slapped in front of cover. Jadeja half-stops with a dive and concedes one
Angling in on a length on middle, clipped to square leg

Slower through the air down leg, he leaves it be
Fuller on off, keeps it out off the back foot
Quicker and full on leg, he gets down and sweeps it fine. Siraj runs around from deep backward square leg and dives but is unable to stop that

commentTextItems.html: And Mominul attacks. Jadeja gives it a bit more air, lands it full on middle, he slogs it over midwicket for the second four off the over

commentTextItems.html: slightly wide outside off without much movement, left alone easily

commentPreTextItems.html: Rohit and Siraj changing the field a little. There's a short midwicket in place, so expect the ball to come in for the flick

commentTextItems.html: he swings it in, as expect, but it's driven on the off side by Litton

commentPreTextItems.html: Short midwicket has crossed the pitch to become silly mid-off
Nandha: "Hi Sudharsanan, are there any changes to the sessions today?" Yup, lunch is at 11.45am. Second session 12.25pm to 2.40pm. And the last from 3pm to 5pm

commentTextItems.html: and beaten! He draws Litton into the drive again and this time beats the outside edge

dismissalText.commentary: Litton Das c Sharma b Mohammed Siraj 13 (30b 3x4 0x6 46m) SR: 43.33

commentTextItems.html: that is a one-handed stunner from Rohit at mid-off! He has not only stunned Litton but might have stunned himself too. Litton countered with a step down the pitch for a powerful whack and it looked like he was going to clear mid-off after middling the horizontal slap. Rohit stayed quite still right until the end when he leapt slightly to stick his right hand up and pull it out of thin air. And he holds the arm cup in celebration. Litton is not able to move, he can't believe it!

stays still this time and defends in front of middle and leg

commentPreTextItems.html: Siraj goes around now

commentTextItems.html: 138.2kmh, angles the short ball in now and it's wide enough outside off to let it go
back of length outside off, Mominul waits and steers it to point

commentPreTextItems.html: The two fielders deep on the leg side are fine leg and long leg

commentTextItems.html: 136.6kmh, short ball but not a bouncer at all and not nasty either. Mominul places it behind square by using the angle and beats fine leg for four. Siraj is unhappy with KL Rahul's effort in the deep

a misfield this time at midwicket and four more! This was a better short ball from Siraj with the bounce. Mominul had to adjust to pull it away and once the ball went through Gill in the circle, it beat Rahul again, even though he wasn't running as fast as he can
ends the over with another short ball, this time Mominul pulls it straight to Rahul. So no need to chase the ball

commentPreTextItems.html: Two left-hand batters, no Ashwin yet. We still have 40 minutes for lunch though, that's about eight overs at least. Oh, here comes Ashwin on demand! Around the wicket with a slip and short leg

commentTextItems.html: 91.7kmh, on length outside off and he slices it square on off
errs too much on leg and the sweep is stopped by Gill, position at short fine leg
better delivery, on length around off and he defends it back
gets the top edge off the sweep but that's gone very wide of Gill at short fine leg and Jadeja sprints to his left in the deep to keep it to one
Shakib comes down for his first ball against Ashwin and drives that beautifully through the covers, inside out and in the gap!

dismissalText.commentary: Shakib Al Hasan c Mohammed Siraj b Ashwin 9 (17b 2x4 0x6 24m) SR: 52.94

commentTextItems.html: make that stunner number two of the day! Ashwin has struck in his first over and more than half the credit for that might go to Siraj for running back, he might have been looking into the sun, and grabbing that with a backward dive! Shakib came down the track and lost one hand off the bat, like Pant, but didn't middle that at all, unlike Pant. Siraj was in the circle at mid-off, and the ball went pretty high into the sky. It's very sunny today and Siraj, wearing shades, kept his eyes on the ball while back-pedalling and leapt back to grab it with his left hand. He's ended up as the Vitruvian man on the field

commentImages.caption: Mohammed Siraj took a one-handed catch while falling over backwards to dismiss Shakib Al Hasan

commentPreTextItems.html: 15 minutes more for lunch, because of the extension today. Oh, hello! Mehidy is getting some attention on his knee. Cold water being poured on his knee because he has been stung by a wasp! Not much of a delay, he's getting ready to resume and is not on strike
"Never seen so many comments being published when Jadeja and Ash are bowling in tandem. Impressive stuff!" Apaar, can you book a hand massage for me?

commentTextItems.html: what a way to enter the 90s! He reaches out for the fullish ball on off and lofts that straight down the ground, over the umpire's head, towards the sight screen for a six!
95.4kmh, Jadeja quickens things up with a flatter delivery on leg, it's tucked to square leg
sweeps the fuller ball and finds short fine this time
on length, on leg again, and he gently defends to short leg
fuller delivery on the stumps and it's flicked past midwicket for one
on the back foot for the flat delivery at 95.6kmh outside off, defends carefully

commentPostTextItems.html: Batting against the spin duo of Ashwin and Jadeja in Indian conditions, six down for under 200, it takes some courage and confidence to smash Jadeja for six down the ground

Ashwin slows it down, he goes ahead with the sweep anyway, and the ball lobs off the edge past Pant for two
shorter and a bit too much on leg, he goes back and defends patiently close to himself

commentPostTextItems.html: 11.46am That's lunch then and India will be pretty happy with the three wickets they took in this extended session. Two of those three were possible because of one-handed stunners Rohit and Siraj will never forget, dismissing two batters - Litton and Shakib - who wanted to attack the bowlers. It could have been three one-handed catches when Siraj was brought back just before lunch, when Mominul was on 95, but the ball didn't stick in Kohli's left hand at slip. Mominul then brought up a smashing century in the next over with a sweep that sumps up his innings and confidence. He has been attacking the loose deliveries, sweeping with self-belief, and not going into a shell at all even against Ashwin and Jadeja bowling together, which hardly gives batters time to breathe.

A reminder that we have extended sessions today. The second session will be 12.25pm to 2.40 and the last from 3pm to 5pm, with the extra half hour hopefully allowed by light. Sudarshanan will be with you all for the next session.
"What a birthday for Mominul! Happy birthday to him!" Belated, Soham. But he'll take it
Sukanya : "Mominul Chose a tasty lunch vs a nervous lunch !!! What a knock!!!"

Elsewhere, 40-year-old Sunil Chhetri is back in goal-scoring form for Bengaluru FC in the Indian Super League and he's also playing with a smile. The signs are there and the former India player is showing glimpses of his best.

commentTextItems.html: Beaten for pace! Length ball around off, 139.2kph, Taijul hung back to glide it but the ball seamed back in just a touch to beat the inside edge at knock off pole. In fact, on further look at the replays, there did not seem to be much seam movement. It was pure pace that Taijul was done in by

commentImages.caption: Taijul Islam had no answers for Jasprit Bumrah's pace and movement

commentPreTextItems.html: Jadeja brought on

commentTextItems.html: Flatter and on a length on middle, he deadbats it

dismissalText.commentary: Khaled Ahmed c & b Jadeja 0 (4b 0x4 0x6 10m) SR: 0

commentTextItems.html: Wicket No. 300 in Tests for Jadeja. He is the second-quickest to the mark of 300 wickets and 3000 runs in the format. Tosses it up fuller on middle, Khaled looks to turn it across but gets a leading edge. One of the more simple catching chances for Jadeja in his career

commentPostTextItems.html: 1:11pm Bangladesh lose 28 for 4 in the 50 balls after lunch. Quick wickets would have been on India's mind today, they have got it done. Mominul stays unbeaten and what an innings it has been from him. All of India's bowlers being among the wickets as Bangladesh have lost 7 for 126 runs to be bowled out. Join us shortly for India's reply

commentImages.caption: Akash Deep joined Ravindra Jadeja for the 300th Test wicket celebration
commentImages.longCaption: Akash Deep joined Ravindra Jadeja for the 300th Test wicket celebration, India vs Bangladesh, 2nd Test, 4th day, Kanpur, September 30, 2024

commentImages.caption: Ravindra Jadeja took a return catch to reach 300 Test wickets
commentImages.longCaption: Ravindra Jadeja took a return catch to reach 300 Test wickets, 2nd Test, 4th day, Kanpur, September 30, 2024

commentPreTextItems.html: Hasan Mahmud to start off proceedings with the ball. Two slips and two gullies stand for Jaiswal's edge

1:20pm Welcome again, folks! Rohit Sharma and Yashasvi Jaiswal make their way out to the middle, following the Bangladesh fielders onto the middle. India's approach in this innings will be an interesting watch. Over four hours left in the India, including the extra half hour

commentTextItems.html: Begins with a length ball on middle, not much pace as Jaiswal pushes it back towards the bowler
Shapes in down leg from a length, he has an attempt at flicking but misses
Thrashed away for the first boundary. Length ball angling away, not much shape in. Width on offer and Jaiswal thumps it through cover
Superb short. Fuller on middle and leg, 135.7kph, it swings in just a touch. Jaiswal leans forward adjusts for the inward movement and punches it back past the bowler
A hat-trick of fours for Jaiswal. This is short and wide, proper hit-me ball at 133.7kph. He obliges by dispatching it through backward point

commentPreTextItems.html: Oh, the umpires having a look at the ball already

commentTextItems.html: Around the wicket, lands it on a length just outside off at 136.7kph, he defends it solidly towards point.

commentTextItems.html: Ohohoho it's a beauty! Rohit off the mark in some style. You need to see no more in case you want to guess India's approach. He dances down to the length ball at 132kph, and swings it wayyyy over long-on

commentPreTextItems.html: The ball is resting on the roof of one of the shamianas. VIshal tells me that it was Khaled's first ball in Tests after six month

commentTextItems.html: Two in a row! Back of a length just outside off, Rohit hangs back and pulls it into the filled stands at deep square leg
Swinging down leg on a length, he misses the flick and Litton palms it away
Back of a length just outside off, climbs more and beats the outside edge of Jaiswal, who looks to slash that
Fuller outside off, driven to mid-off

commentPreTextItems.html: Once again the ball is taken to the umpire for a shape-check. Looks fine

commentTextItems.html: Toe-ended through slips. A hint of shape away after it lands on a length around of, Jaiswal goes back to punch it but manages to get it between first and second slip. Shanto can't help but look away

commentTextItems.html: Beaten! And a belated appeal from Bangladesh. Mehidy walks in from cover and says he heard something, even though the bowler and the wicketkeeper say they did not hear anything. Shaping away from a length outside off, he feels for it and is beaten. There was a bottom edge, Snicko confirms it! Oh, Mehidy! If only they listened to you

Miles in the air and out of the ground. Rohit backs away early, Mahmud follows him with a length ball and sees it flies over wide long-on. "Someone tell Rohit he has retired from T20Is," says DK on air
Low full toss on the pad, flicked to deep square leg
Yorker on middle from around the wicket, he squeezes it out towards mid-on. Rohit wants a run but is sent back. Makes it in despite the direct hit

Lofted over extra cover! This looks like some video game. Full and outside off, 122.5kph, Jaiswal as enough room to free his arms and pummel it over. It was the slower one as Mahmud rolled his fingers over

commentPreTextItems.html: Some stats jewel, courtesy Sampath:
Players to hit sixes off their first two balls in a men's Test innings: (where known)
Foffie Williams (off Jim Laker) in 1948
Sachin Tendulkar (off Nathan Lyon) in 2013
Umesh Yadav (off George Linde) in 2019
Rohit Sharma (off Khaled Ahmed) in 2024

commentTextItems.html: Shortish and angling in, Jaiswal is a tad early into the pull. But he adjusts and rolls his hands to hit it through backward square leg. "It's just another manic Monday," sings Ravi Shastri on air
Fifty up for India in just three overs! Yorker outside off, Jaiswal squeezed it out while opening the face of the bat to get it through backward point. Fastest team fifty in men's Tests!

comments.title: Mehidy Hasan Miraz to Rohit Sharma

commentPreTextItems.html: India are speeding away, so Bangladesh try to slow them down by bringing on spin. Mehidy Hasan Miraz into the attack. Only a slip close in

commentTextItems.html: Welcomed with a four! Rohit in some mood. Tossed up ball on middle, he clears his front leg and wallops it through midwicket. The fielder in the deep is quite wide

comments.title: Mehidy Hasan Miraz to Rohit Sharma

commentTextItems.html: Anticipates the charge and fires it in on a length, he keeps it out to short midwicket

comments.title: Mehidy Hasan Miraz to Rohit Sharma

commentTextItems.html: Fires it down leg, he misses the swipe

comments.title: Mehidy Hasan Miraz to Rohit Sharma

commentTextItems.html: Mehidy thinks he has Rohit lbw, but is it sliding down? Fired in on a length, angling in as well. It pitched around of and middle. Rohit goes back to heave it away and is hit high on the front pad. The angle looks like it is headed down, Hawk-Eye will confirm shortly, leg stump also looks to be visible between Rohit's legs. The impact is outside leg!

comments.title: Mehidy Hasan Miraz to Rohit Sharma

dismissalText.commentary: Rohit Sharma b Mehidy Hasan Miraz 23 (11b 1x4 3x6 23m) SR: 209.09

commentTextItems.html: Spins in sharply through him! Kanpur is stunned into silence. Rohit is furious and cannot believe it. Mehidy tosses it up nicely, lands it on a length outside off. Rohit comes on to the front foot but is not to the pitch of it, so tries to keep it out by transferring his weight back. But the ball turns back in sharply, keeps a bit low and beats him on the inside to clatter the stumps. Mehidy is delighted, job done

commentImages.caption: Mehidy Hasan Miraz breached Rohit Sharma's defence in his first over
commentImages.longCaption: Mehidy Hasan Miraz breached Rohit Sharma's defence in his first over, 2nd Test, 4th day, Kanpur, September 30, 2024

commentTextItems.html: a bit flat outside off and he slices it away to backward point
hint of width outside off and Jasiwal rocks back in the crease to cut that away square and find the gap on the off side for four, just behind square in fact
overcompensates the length as it's pitched up and this time it's a flourishing drive on the other side of deep cover for four more!
presses forward and defends with compact technique
bat close to pad again and he blocks yet again
covers the line of the stumps carefully for the flat delivery and defends to end the over

commentPostTextItems.html: The fastest Test half-century is Misbah's in 21 balls and for an Indian it's Pant's off 28 balls. Jaiswal can break that record

commentTextItems.html: 91.2kmh, goes back in the crease for a big whip to deep midwicket
92.8kmh, bit too straight on middle and leg, Gill gets down quickly and sweeps that away behind square, against the turn and that's raced to the boundary
a punch off the back foot to deep cover for one

given out caught behind and Pant has reviewed that. Pant went for a hard-handed cut off the back foot and he reviewed without consulting Gill. No spike at all on UltraEdge and Pant gets the decision overturned
Tossed up full outside off, driven along the ground to point
Tossed full on off, eased to long-off, and that will be tea

commentPostTextItems.html: 2.43pm That's tea then, and India have waltzed to 138 in just 16 overs, going at close to nine an over. It was Rohit's sixes from his very first ball that set the tone for this carnage. He led from the front, powered India past 50 in just three overs and India broke the record for the fastest fifty and 100 in Test cricket. An 11-ball 23 from him, a 31-ball fifty from Jasiwal and it's Gill and a promoted Pant taking India forward now. They're just 95 runs behind, 40 overs to go in the day, where is this Test headed? Sudarshanan will start the final session with you all...

commentTextItems.html: Full on middle, flicked to long leg on the bounce. And Khaled has overstepped

Massive mix-up, Kohli survives. It is a slower one outside off, Kohli reaches for the drive and inside edges it onto the pad and it rolls to the off side. He runs down for a quick run, and Pant responded initially before sending him back. Khaled, meanwhile, had got to the ball, so Kohli did not even try to get back. But instead of breaking the stumps, Khaled tried to underarm the throw and missed
Rubbing salt to Khaled's wounds. Slower length ball on middle, Kohli is a tad early into the pull. Toe-ends it to beat fine leg to bring up the fastest 150 in men's Tests
As authoritative as it gets. Length ball outside off, slightly on the fuller side, Kohli comes down and lofts it inside out over cover
Slower one again, on a fullish length, punched through wide mid-off
Wristy flick to the full ball angled in, straight to deep midwicket on the bounce

commentTextItems.html: Another miscue, Pant falls now. Shakib slows it down, tosses it up wider outside off. Pant gets down on a knee to slog it over the on side but has to fetch it from outside off. Ends up dragging it to Mahmud at long-on. India losing some quick wickets in quest for quick runs...

commentPreTextItems.html: KL Rahul is in next, six on the fence for the new batter as well

The ball holds on the surface a bit and Kohli chips it wide of extra cover
Spins away outside off, he waits and steers it to deep backward point
Quicker and shorter outside off, keeps low and skids on. Kohli goes back to pull but gets an inside edge onto his back leg

Thick edge for four. Full and wider outside off, 136.5kph, Kohli jumps down the track and goes pushing at that, almost on purpose. The edge does not matter as deep third is not too fine. And the slip cordon is vacant too

Length ball outside off, hangs back and guides it to deep third

"This was the type of innings India wanted from KL on the 19th of November last year...." Ouch! It's a team sport, Syed Kamran. India didn't lose only because of Rahul

Bj: "Hi Vishal. No way we will get 75 mins of play here. So I believe India will try to score as much as they can today and then declare overnight.Your thoughts?" Who knows India will declare today itself to bowl a little before stumps. Maybe for half hour?

commentTextItems.html: towards the leg side with the angle, Jadeja goes for a paddle kind of sweep and misses

commentTextItems.html: that's a strange dismissal, the umpire's finger has silenced the crowd and Jadeja is walking off! He came down the track and Mehidy did well to drop it short and hit him on the pad. The ball then lobbed to Shanto at cover and he's been given out caught. That must have been bat-pad then

commentTextItems.html: off the mark with a deft and late touch fine on the off side for one towards deep third
96.2kmh, darts it just outside off, and Rahul pulls that with some power to deep midwicket. Mehidy is not going to give any flight here

commentPreTextItems.html: Rohit is ready in his playing attire, tying his shoe laces. Declaration coming soon?

commentTextItems.html: what's happening here! Ashwin goes for the reverse and Mehidy pitches it way down the leg side, now off side and Ashwin is left a little surprised
flat on off stump and it's chipped to midwicket after a bounce

dismissalText.long: st †Litton Das b Mehidy Hasan Miraz
dismissalText.commentary: KL Rahul st †Litton Das b Mehidy Hasan Miraz 68 (43b 7x4 2x6 62m) SR: 158.13

commentTextItems.html: Beaten by bounce as he comes down the track and KL Rahul is stumped! Mehidy smartly bowled that short and outside off after seeing Rahul dancing down. The batter tried to whack it on off but the bounce beat his bat, Litton collected that around chest height off a spinner and did well to take the bails off

commentPreTextItems.html: Rohit looks ready but India are not declaring yet. They lead by 51. Bumrah the new man

commentTextItems.html: gets some width first ball and he happily steers over the covers for one

comments.title: Mehidy Hasan Miraz to Akash Deep

commentPreTextItems.html: Ankush Kulkarni: "@Vishal1686 In case India declared, is the light OK for the play to continue? " Right now, yes, but we have an hour left

commentTextItems.html: a big slog sweep from Akash Deep, he misses it but there's an appeal for caught behind and Shanto has reviewed it. It stayed a bit low after pitching outside off and there's nothing on UltraEdge

commentTextItems.html: don't pitch it up to him! Akash Deep has smoked that down the ground but on this occasion it doesn't have the distance and a tumbling long-on gets under it

commentPostTextItems.html: 4.34pm With that, India have declared! Sorry, Siraj. you won't get to smash some sixes here. That's 285 for 9 then, India lead by 52 here, and we discount the 10 minutes for innings break, they will have about 45 minutes to bowl today. Depends on them how many overs they can manage in that. Maybe 10? Who would have thought this morning what we were going to witness what we have just witnessed? Even a ray of sunshine felt like such a blessing after yesterday's disappointment. And now, after bowling out Bangladesh, India have hammered close to 300 runs in under 35 overs at over eight an over! Rohit Sharma set the tone like a true leader, along with Jaiswal, and India's famed line-up only had to follow their footsteps. Jaiswal hit some classy strokes, Kohli and Rahul peppered some boundaries with the occasional sixes and their strategy of getting quick runs for nearly three hours has worked so far. Now they want some wickets, will that happen too?

Got to feel for the two Bangladesh quicks today - Khaled and Hasan. They were plundered for 50 runs in just three overs as India went on to break records. They only got some relief when Mehidy dismissed Rohit, and even though the runs continued, at least the spinners brought the run rate down and picked wickets too. Mehidy and Shakib take four each out of the nine.
